newsitem.title: USA: Smoke-trial jurors complain fees a month behind.
newsitem.headline: Smoke-trial jurors complain fees a month behind.

text.p: Jurors in a $5 billion secondhand smoke case complained on Tuesday that they had not been paid their $30 a day fees for about a month.
"I'll do what I can," Dade County Circuit Judge Robert Kaye told the jurors, promising to talk to court administrators. "But they're like the IRS."

Six jurors and seven alternate jurors have been hearing testimony since July 14, when lawyers for 60,000 non-smoking flight attendants began calling scientists, physicians and public health officials as witnesses to press their claim secondhand smoke sickened the flight attendants. Tobacco companies deny the smoke caused the injuries.
Testimony in the case is expected to last through September. Six jurors will then decide the case.

One male juror told Kaye that he and other jurors, who include a cable-television installer and a postal worker, had received payment for only two weeks, including fees for days served before July 14.
Jurors working for employers with staff of 10 or more are entitled to their regular wages while on jury duty, according to Florida law.
